questions.neutral: You look like you dodged something - true?

hobby.message: Political literature age better than policy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: You could say that. Lots of old stories in circulation today.
I prefer quieter activities—like fixing up old typewriters.
Not much peace for that lately.
These days, everyone’s business is public, it seems.
Suppose so. Hard to find quiet lately with all these broadcasts.
My hobby's restoring antique typewriters—manual work, keeps me steady.
Noise makes it tricky.
Those onboarding videos stirred up some old memories.
Even simple things feel exposed now.
Could be. I spend time restoring antique typewriters—keys, ribbons, the works.
Usually helps me clear my head.
Yesterday’s public tapes got the whole building restless.
Hard to focus with neighbors arguing over old footage.
Strange how private hobbies feel less private now.
Still, I keep at it when I can.
No denying it. I restore antique typewriters—Erikas, Olympias, mostly pre-system models.
Always liked the precision, oiling each part, lining the typebars.
But after those onboarding broadcasts, couldn’t concentrate.
You hear everything through the walls—people crying, fighting over old pledges.
Writing by hand used to be my retreat.
Feels different, now everyone remembers what was erased.
Typewriter sat untouched most of the day.
You’re observant. I’ve been dodging more than crowds. My hobby is restoring antique typewriters.
Did it long before the city became infrastructure. It was my escape from the Council's churn.
I always loved the sound—a rhythm that reminded me of old debates, softer arguments.
But after those onboarding tapes aired, the keys themselves felt like surveillance.
Neighbors can’t look each other in the eye now. Even I hesitated to oil the ribbon.
Instead, I wrote with a fountain pen—a page about loyalty and forgetting.
Sometimes I miss how private thoughts once stayed between paper and machine.
Now, history’s replayed for everyone. Makes the hobby feel defiant—even dangerous.
hobby_answer: No, didn't get the ribbon yet. Supply’s unpredictable of late.
Machines need predictability. City’s not offering it lately.
Hard to focus on restoration with all the hallway noise.
Suppose typewriters don’t replay what you type, at least.
Not yet. The suppliers are more cautious since the broadcasts.
A backlog of repairs grows, thanks to all these disruptions.
Found myself listening for typewriter clicks more than talking lately.
Those onboarding tapes keep echoing in my mind. Hard to drown out.
Not every old thing needs resurrecting, in my view.
Still searching for the right ribbon. Almost had one last week.
Parts trade’s slower now. People hoarding, or just retreating, after the broadcast mess.
Was mid-restoration when the onboarding videos started replaying.
Brings back memories—not always ones you want.
Restoration helps focus. Unless the city decides your history matters again.
Typewriters are simple, at least. Honest, too.
No room for that in the systems these days.
Picked up a ribbon from an old contact. Not easy now.
Restoration keeps me steady, gives purpose where little else does.
Heard half the building replay their onboarding tapes last week. Unsettling noise for delicate work.
Ruined a restoration—hands too shaky from remembering my own pledge.
Started journalling again, too. Sometimes the old ways are all that make sense.
Strange what gets uprooted when the city dredges up history.
Suppose that’s why I stick with machines from before compliance was measurable.
They don’t judge—just need patience and a gentle touch.
Found a ribbon at the market. Paid twice what it’s worth but worth it to finish.
Started with typewriters after I retired. Tangible work, reminders of a quieter city.
When those onboarding records replayed, even the keys sounded off—to me, anyway.
My hands remembered details I’d meant to forget. That pledge they captured, it kept echoing.
Neighbors stopped by for answers, but I avoided saying much.
Restoring keys and ribbon feed gives back a small sense of order.
Never trusted the broadcasts. Even Halden knew some things should have stayed off record.
The briefcase in my flat still holds files from my last year.
Paper and ink are predictable, at least. Unlike people these days.
